Posts.Title: Docetaxal and dry throat/mouth

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone! Sorry it's taken me ages to reply, my dry mouth and throat became a hideous tickly cough and high temp overnight and I've been in hospital for some of today being checked over. I'm back home with some penicillin now and hoping to kick this cold soon.  Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal and dry throat/mouth

Posts.Content: Hello I'm up to day 7 of my first cycle of docetaxal. So far, it's behaving fairly well... Just wondered whether anyone had any advice for a dry throat/mouth? I'm using a mild alcohol free mouthwash already and have been drinking plenty of warm drinks. Anything else that might help? Thank you! Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxal and dry throat/mouth

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone! Great news that you've got the go ahead too, Ali!  Good luck Nettie, LittleSusie and GrannyLara! Welcome to the club, Vickie (although sorry you had to join in the first place!) I was more worried about chemo than surgery too, mainly because I knew I would only need to do surgery once and I would be asleep whilst they got on with it. I was very nervous for my first FEC, but less so for my second. I was also lucky with my FEC side effects. Hope you continue to be. Good luck for tomorrow afternoon! Not sure I'll have time to be online tomorrow morning - got to get my 6 year old ready for a pyjama day at school before I head off to the hospital. So sending you all hugs now. See you on the other side... Caroline xxx

Hopefully we'll finish at around the same time tomorrow. Caroline xx

Hope FEC 2 went well for you this afternoon, Vickie! Well done Mena and Ali (and anyone just clearing the finishing line!) Good luck to everyone else on the chemo road... You can do it! Caroline xxx

Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Hello! It's nearly a week since I finished radiotherapy and it's time to start thinking about going back to work. I have an admin role looking after a team of people. It's fairly full on for the 25hrs I work a week. Before I go back I need to meet with the company occupational health dept so that they can advise on a phased return to work. The thing is I'm not sure what I need to ask for. I feel fine sat at home, but don't know whether returning to the office will be exhausting. Any thoughts or experiences that might help guide me? Thank you! Caroline x

Posts.Content: Thank you both!  Caroline x

Posts.Title: yahooo

Posts.Content: Congratulations, R! Getting to the end of chemo feels great, doesn't it? Good luck with the rest of your treatment. Caroline x
Posts.Title: Final chemo done.... woohoo!!

Posts.Content: Hi Katee I had all of my lymph nodes removed from one side (complete axillary clearance) and it's not as scary as it sounds on paper. Mine were removed in October and I've not had any signs of lymphedema. You have to be more careful when shaving (electric razor rather than wet shaving) and you'll need to follow the exercise advice given after surgery too. Don't worry too much though, just follow BCN advice and hopefully all will be fine.  Caroline xx
Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: Thanks Susie and Mo I'm fine, honestly. :) Just feeling a bit cooped up at the moment - my husband works full-time during the week and takes the car to work whilst I stay at home (in a village). The first couple of months off work were lovely, but I'm used to being far busier than this during the day. All of my friends and family are working during the day so I'm just whiling away the hours between school runs. Once it gets a bit warmer I'll start going for walks again, but it's too cold and muddy here at the moment. I've managed 15 weeks of chemo and no takeaways/eating out so it seems silly to risk it for my last 3 weeks. I know that you mean about waiting rooms Mo, I caught a cough from the cancer clinic a few weeks ago and became neutropenic. I don't fancy going through that again, hence avoiding the public as much as possible. :) Last chemo next Thursday do I'm nearly there... Caroline x
Posts.Title: Good Morning Ali Owl

Posts.Content: Hi Ali Glad to see you back online. :) Sorry you had another rough night. Hopefully the antibiotic and painkiller combo will work some wonders for you soon. I'm ok. Starting to feel a bit bored sitting at home all day. I would like to see the Second Best Marigold Hotel too! I saw the first film whilst I was recovering from FEC chemo and loved it. As with you I'm waiting until I finish chemo before going though - my oncologist was quite strict about not going to the cinema/crowded places, eating out or getting takeaways whilst I was having chemo. I cannot wait to finish chemo just so that I can go out properly!  Hope you have a better night tonight.  Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Good Morning Ali Owl

Posts.Content: Hi Ali How are you feeling this morning? Did you get any sleep last night? Hope things are brighter for you today. Caroline x
Posts.Title: Good Morning Ali Owl

Posts.Content: Hello! I'm feeling pretty good. My cough has finally lifted a bit after annoying me for a week and so far tax has been nicer to me than the first few days after FEC. I was very happy not to get the hot flush on the first night after chemo this time and I had enough energy to take my daughter to school the following day - when I was on FEC I'd struggle to be up before 9! Today, my sinuses have felt  blocked and my sense of taste seems to have gone a bit funny but otherwise all is good. I'm trying not to be complacent though in case tax is planning to floor me next week...  No snow in Norwich at the moment... Hope you both start to feel a bit better soon. Good luck with the meds next week. Caroline xxx
Posts.Title: how u all doin ?

Posts.Content: Hello A quick question about cording if I may... I started radiotherapy this week and have been much more aware of that part of my body as a result. I've had a few twinges around the scar line of my lumpectomy, but put that down to an overly tight bra (thanks for the weight gain chemo!). This afternoon I noticed a thin rope like line running along the edge of my arm pit above where I had my lymph nodes removed. It's not the same under my 'normal' arm. I've also noticed that my arm can feel tight sometimes like something is pulling slightly when I stretch it out. Could this be cording? My surgery was back in October and I was doing arm exercises until mid-Feb. If it is cording is there anything I can do to ease it? Thank you! Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Cording?

Posts.Content: Thank you both! I've just had a chat with my BCN. She agrees that it sounds like cording. As it's not causing me any pain and it isn't restricting my movement she has asked me to do some arm exercises for two weeks. If it hasn't improved by then she'll refer me to a physio. Thanks for reassuring me last night. :) Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Cording?

Posts.Content: Hi June I think you may be in a similar position to me. I found a lump in August and was diagnosed with a Grade 1 cancer in September. The biopsy results showed that there were also signs of cancer in one of my lymph nodes so I was sent for a CT scan and bone scan to see if there was any suspicious cell activity elsewhere in my body.My operation (lumpectomy and complete axillary clearance - removal of all lymph nodes on the affected side) took place in October. It was a day procedure so after being operated on at lunchtime I was home by mid-evening. It's good to have someone with you for 24 hrs after the op to be on the safe side.  Cancer cells were found in 7 of my lymph glands, but it didn't look like the cancer had spread elsewhere. I was told that I would have to have radiotherapy and 5 yrs of tamoxifen because the cancer had gone to my lymph nodes. I was also given the option of FEC-T chemotherapy, more as a preventative measure to decrease the chance of the cancer coming back. I'm currently halfway through chemo. It's not as bad as I imagined it would be and I'm glad I chose to do it. It is scary being diagnosed and waiting for things to happen. It sounds you like you have some good friends though. If what I've said sounds similar to your situation I'm happy to keep in touch to let you know how I've been finding each stage. This forum has been great when I've been worried about things. Take care, Caroline x
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: Hi June As mistymoley says it can be just bad luck. It's a massive rollercoaster of emotion when you are first diagnosed. I found that I was shocked (I'd been on a real health kick over the summer and felt great!), devastated and then very angry (quite frankly at 37 I felt too young for cancer!). I've harnessed the anger and turned it into defiance. There is no way this is beating me! Once you've had the op you may feel better. At least the lump will be gone!  I've not noticed any great change to my overall health since the lymph glands were removed. Under my arm is still numb many weeks later and may well stay that way forever. It's not uncomfortable, just feels a bit alien when I spray deodorant there and can't feel it! The only thing I wasn't prepared for after the op was a build up of seroma (fluid like in a blister) 10 days later. It became very uncomfortable and did dampen my spirits, I'd been so pleased I was on the mend. It was drained by my BCN once and then again by my surgeon and since then it's been behaving. I'm taking part in a clinical trial aimed at reducing lymphedema risk. I have a set of exercises and a massage to do twice every day for three months. My arm hasn't shown any sign of lymphedema yet. The important thing after the op is to do the exercises that the hospital recommends. I found that going for walks helped too. It gave me time to think whilst I waited for my first chemo appointment and I felt like I was training myself for the next stage. My surgeon wasn't the most charismatic person I've ever met, but he knew precisely what he was doing. I found that an appointment with the surgeon would be straight to the point. My BCN would then meet me afterwards to go through details more closely and to offer emotional support. Hopefully you will get that too. If you have any questions or worries please do shout! Good luck! Caroline x
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: Good luck Stoatie! As everyone has said just follow the advice of the nurses (especially about when is best to take anti-sickness tablets) and listen to your body. Keep an eye of your temps and think about keeping a log of how you feel each day. I found that during FEC it was good to be able to read back over how I had felt to see if there was a pattern and to reassure myself on rubbish days that everything has been fine last time around. You can do this and we'll be here for you! As you say once you get started you are already heading for the finish line! Love Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Starting FEC T today

Posts.Content: Thanks Ali Bloods came back ok, so I'm all set for tomorrow at 11. Good luck everybody. Group hug! Caroline xx
Posts.Title: Thursday/ Friday chemo club

Posts.Content: Oh no Mena! That doesn't sound very nice. Glad you are down to just one chemo!  I didn't have to wait too long, only half an hour, but they had trouble with my veins too. They got the needle in on the second attempt. On the first go they managed to go right through the vein! :( I only slept for an hour last night because of the steroids so had a snooze at the hospital. How are you, Ali? Not still flying around the hospital, I hope. One more down... :-) aroline xx
Posts.Title: Thursday/ Friday chemo club

Posts.Content: Thanks Ali! Bloods all done and fingers crossed they come back ok for Thursday. My cough and cold crushed my blood count a week ago, but I think it should have recovered by now. I've had a lovely day looking around Norwich castle and completely forgetting about Thursday's chemo. Starting my steroids tomorrow morning and keeping my fingers crossed that tax is kind to me again this time.  Really pleased to read your good news today! Good luck for Thursday!  Good luck for Friday, Nettie, and good luck to all of the Thursday ladies! One more down... Caroline xx

Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: Hello! Welcome to the club that no one wants to join. I'm sorry that you are feeling so scared. It's certainly a rollercoaster. Hopefully when you see your oncologist on Monday things will seem clearer. If you are worried, need to vent, or just want people to talk to pop onto here. Everyone is friendly and kind and we're all at different stages so there's usually someone that can reassure you about what you are about to go through/are going through. Sending a hug and luck for Monday. Caroline x
